final_answer.precision_note: Result given to 3 significant figures, consistent with the precision of the NaOH concentration (0.150 mol dm-3).

method: First, calculate moles of NaOH used: n(NaOH) = concentration × volume = 0.150 mol dm-3 × (23.40 cm3 / 1000) dm3 = 0.00351 mol. From the balanced equation H2SO4 + 2NaOH -> Na2SO4 + 2H2O, the mole ratio is 1:2, so n(H2SO4) = n(NaOH) / 2 = 0.00351 mol / 2 = 0.001755 mol. The volume of H2SO4 is 25.00 cm3 = 0.02500 dm3. Therefore, concentration of H2SO4 = n / V = 0.001755 mol / 0.02500 dm3 = 0.0702 mol dm-3.
checks: Mole ratio check: From L40, H2SO4 + 2NaOH confirms 1:2 ratio, correctly applied.
Concentration check: 0.001755 mol / 0.02500 dm3 = 0.0702 mol dm-3, consistent with 3 sig figs.
